facts.text: This is a Criminal Appeal No. 20 of 1964 in the Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 20 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 16, 1963 of the Madras High

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated July 16, 1963 of the Madras High Court in Criminal Revision Case No. 1139 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 16, 1963 of the Madras High Court in Criminal Revision Case No. 1139 of 1961  Criminal Revis

facts.text: Appellant was charged with offences under s. 420 IPC and s. 21(d) and (e) of the Forward Contracts Regulation Act, 1952 regarding transactions with PW.2 Rajam.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was charged for having committed offences under s. 420, Indian Penal Code and s. 21 d  and  e  of the Forward Contracts  Regulation  Act, 1952

facts.text: Appellant was convicted by District Magistrate, Kumbakonam of all charges and sentenced to RI for one year and fine Rs.1000 under s.420 IPC, fine Rs.100 under each of s.21(d) and (e), with Rs.1000 out of fine to PW.2.

issues.text: Whether a case of cheating under section 420 of the Indian Penal Code has been made out against the appellant?

anchor.surface_text: It was argued, in the first place, on behalf of the appellant that on the admitted or proved facts no case of cheating has been made out against the appellant and therefore his conviction under s. 420, Indian Penal Code was illegal. We are unable to accept this argument as correct. It has

issues.text: Whether the forward contract in question was a wagering contract falling outside the purview of the Forward Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1952?

anchor.surface_text: It was then submitted on behalf of the appellant that the forward contract in the present case was a wagering contract and fell outside the purview of the Act and the provisions of s. 15 of that Act were therefore no attracted to this case. issues.text: Whether speculative contracts ostensibly for delivery of goods but without real intention of delivery fall within the definition of 'forward contract' under section 2(c) of the Forward Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1952?

Whether there was a breach of section 15 of the Forward Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1952, notwithstanding the appellant's claim of placing orders through a member of a recognised association while acting as pucca adatia?
Whether the alleged breach of section 361 of the Criminal Procedure Code vitiated the trial?
Whether the joinder of six items of cheating in a single charge was illegal?

arguments.claim: no case of cheating has been made out against the appellant under s. 420 IPC

anchor.surface_text: It was argued, in the first place, on behalf of the appellant that on the admitted or proved facts no case of cheating has been made out against the appellant and therefore his conviction under s. 420, Indian Penal Code was illegal. We are unable to accept this argument as correct.

holdings.text: A case of cheating under section 420 of the Indian Penal Code has been made out against the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued, in the first place, on behalf of the appellant that on the admitted or proved facts no case of cheating has been made out against the appellant and therefore his conviction under s. 420, Indian Penal Code was illegal. We are unable to accept this argument as correct. It has

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant made false representation in Ex.P-34 that he could conduct forward business lawfully knowing he was not entitled as non-member, inducing PW2 to part with Rs.12,000.

holdings.text: The forward contract in question is not a wagering contract falling outside the purview of the Forward Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: It was then submitted on behalf of the appellant that the forward contract in the present case was a wagering contract and fell outside the purview of the Act and the provisions of s. 15 of that Act were therefore no attracted to this case. In our opinion, there is no justification

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act regulates forward trading including speculative to curb abuses; wagering contracts within scope per legislative purpose.

holdings.text: Speculative contracts ostensibly for delivery of goods but without real intention of delivery fall within the definition of 'forward contract' under section 2(c) of the Forward Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1952.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation using mischief rule (Heydon's case, Bengal Immunity) to include speculative contracts to suppress unregulated speculation and effectuate Act's regulation purpose.

holdings.text: There was a breach of section 15 of the Forward Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1952, as appellant acted as pucca adatia without placing orders through recognised association member.

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, there is no evidence on the record of the case to show that the appellant placed the order for the notified goods with a member of the recognised association. But even on the assumption that the appellant placed an order for the notified goods through a member

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of orders through member; pucca adatia acts principal to principal with no privity to association merchant (precedents: Bhagwandas cases).

holdings.text: The alleged breach of section 361 of the Criminal Procedure Code did not vitiate the trial.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Violation if any is mere irregularity causing no prejudice; no objection raised, represented by counsel knowing languages; cured by s.537 CrPC.

holdings.text: Joinder of six items of cheating in a single charge was not illegal.
holdings.reasoning_summary: All six items part of one transaction; permissible under s.239 CrPC.

holdings.text: The decision of the High Court affirming convictions and sentences under s.420 IPC and s.21(d),(e) of the Act should be affirmed.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons expressed we hold that the decision of the High Court should be affirmed, and this.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All arguments rejected; lower courts' findings on facts and law upheld.

anchor.surface_text: That was the rule laid down in Heydons case 1  which was accepted by this Court in The Bengal Immunity Company Limited v. The State of Bihar and others 2 . As we have already pointed out, the Act was passed in order to put a stop to undesirable forms of speculation in forward trading and to companyrect the abuses of certain forms of forward trading in the wide interests of the companymunity and, in particular, the interests of the companysumers for whom adequate safeguards were essential.

precedents.cited_proposition: rule of interpretation that a statute should be so construed as to prevent the mischief and to advance remedy according to the true intention of the makers of the statute, having regard to history, mischief and remedy

precedents.citation: The Bengal Immunity Company Limited v. The State of Bihar and others 2

anchor.surface_text: Heydons case 1  which was accepted by this Court in The Bengal Immunity Company Limited v. The State of Bihar and others 2 . As we have already pointed out, the Act was passed in order to put a stop to undesirable forms of speculation in forward trading and to companyrect the abuses of certain forms of forward trading in the wide interests of the companymunity and, in particular, the interests of the companysumers for whom adequate safeguards were essential. In our opinion, speculative companytracts of the type companyered in the present case are included within the purview of the Act.

edges.explanation: The issue explicitly questions whether the forward contract was a wagering contract, directly addressing the cluster concept UNLISTED_WAGERING_CONTRACT.
Resolving the issue of interpreting 'forward contract' under s.2(c) to include speculative contracts requires application of Mischief Rule.
The issue i3 directly concerns whether speculative contracts fall within the definition under section 2(c), which is the concept c5.
Resolving issue i3 requires the holding h3 on whether speculative contracts fall within section 2(c).
Issue i4 directly questions breach of section 15 FCRA, which is the concept c4
Issue is addressed by argument that violation is mere irregularity no prejudice.
Issue is addressed by argument on breach claim and mere irregularity response.
Determining whether the breach vitiated the trial (i5) requires consideration of the curative scope of Section 537 CrPC (c10).
Issue of vitiation due to s.361 breach addresses the concept interpretation of s.361 as mere irregularity if no prejudice.
The issue on whether breach of s.361 CrPC vitiated the trial is directly addressed by the holding that it did not.
Issue of joinder legality requires consideration of Section 239 CrPC.
Heydon's Case is the originating precedent that establishes the Mischief Rule (Heydon's Rule) as a rule of interpretation to prevent mischief and advance remedy.
Heydon's Case rule supports the holding through application of Mischief Rule to include speculative contracts in s.2(c).
Bengal Immunity Company Limited v. State of Bihar accepts and applies Heydon's Case rule of interpretation, supporting the Mischief Rule.
Bengal Immunity's acceptance of Heydon's rule supports the holding via Mischief Rule application.
